facts.text: Vallabhdas Liladhar purchased smuggled gold weighing a little more than 84 tolas from an Arab on December 1, 1956.
Vallabhdas Liladhar borrowed Rs. 3,600/- from Narandas Nagjibhai, Vallabhdas Nagjibhai, and Keshavlal Nagjibhai about November 28, 1956, to make the purchase.
After purchase, Vallabhdas Liladhar went to house of Narandas Nagjibhai, Vallabhdas Nagjibhai, and Keshavlal in Porbander, informed them of purchase, sought help in disposal.
Narandas Nagjibhai instructed Vallabhdas Nagjibhai to take gold to Bantwa and sell at Rs. 103/- per tola; if not, contact at Bantwa bus stand to go to Junagadh.
Vallabhdas Nagjibhai proceeded to Bantwa by bus on December 2, 1956 afternoon.

Inspector Mehta received information about smuggling, followed bus, intercepted Vallabhdas Nagjibhai at Kutiyana bus stand at 3 p.m. with Deputy Superintendent; five gold bars weighing 84 tolas recovered, bore foreign origin marks, recovery list prepared.

On October 7, 1957, Collector of Central Excise Baroda confiscated gold under s.167(8) Sea Customs Act read with s.23 Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947, imposed penalty Rs.1,000/- each on three appellants and Rs.500/- on Keshavlal.
Complaint filed by Assistant Collector of Customs under s.167(81) before Porbander magistrate on June 27, 1958.
Vallabhdas Liladhar's defense: gold brought from Karachi in 1946, not purchased from Arab.
Vallabhdas Nagjibhai admitted recovery but claimed gold belonged to Vallabhdas Liladhar, carried at his request, unaware it was smuggled.
Narandas Nagjibhai admitted Vallabhdas Liladhar came with gold but claimed not smuggled, belonged to him for sale.
Keshavlal claimed no knowledge or connection; acquitted by Sessions Judge.
Appellants made statements before customs authorities admitting prosecution case that gold was smuggled and they were trying to dispose of it.
Magistrate convicted all four under s.167(81), sentenced to 6 months RI and Rs.500/- fine.
Additional Sessions Judge acquitted Keshavlal, dismissed appeals of three appellants, upheld convictions and sentences.
High Court rejected revisions of Vallabhdas Liladhar and Vallabhdas Nagjibhai summarily; admitted then dismissed Narandas Nagjibhai's.
High Court judgments dated December 11, 1959 and March 2, 1960.
Leave to appeal to Supreme Court refused by High Court; special leave granted by Supreme Court.
Vallabhdas Liladhar died; his appeal (Cr.A.48/1960) abates.

Circumstances found by all courts: price of gold over Rs.105/tola but intended to sell at Rs.103/tola; appellants goldsmiths at Porbander, no reason to send elsewhere; undue haste; surreptitious manner of keeping gold; loan Rs.3600 entered in name of Liladhar's brother (brother-in-law); foreign markings obvious to goldsmiths; statements to customs; presumption under s.178A.

legal_issues.text: Whether statements made to customs authorities were properly proved.
Whether statements inadmissible under ss.24 and 25 of Indian Evidence Act.
Whether further criminal trial possible after confiscation and penalty under s.167(8) in view of s.186 Sea Customs Act.
Whether ingredients of s.167(81) satisfied, particularly intention to defraud government of duty or evade prohibition/restriction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Statements not properly proved as lawyer who signed them not produced.
Statements inadmissible under ss.24 and 25 Evidence Act.
No further trial after confiscation/penalty under s.167(8) due to s.186 implying bar to prosecution under same Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.186 Sea Customs Act; Leo Roy Frey v. Superintendent

petitioner_arguments.text: Ingredients of s.167(81) not satisfied; no proof of intention to defraud duty or evade prohibition.
Reduce sentence to period undergone as on bail since March 1960.

court_reasoning.text: Statements proved by appellants' admission of signing them; no need to examine lawyer. Courts below rightly disbelieved claim of ignorance of contents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statements bore admitted signatures of appellants.

court_reasoning.text: s.25 Evidence Act inapplicable as customs officers not police officers (State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram); s.24 inapplicable as no inducement/threat/promise found by courts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Customs authorities persons in authority but statements voluntary.

court_reasoning.text: s.186 enabling provision allowing punishment under other laws after customs action; not barring prosecution under same Act, especially post cl.81 introduction in 1955. Leo Roy Frey not on point.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.186 ex abundanti cautela, not a bar.

court_reasoning.text: Once smuggled gold proved, dealing with it knowingly implies intention to evade duty/prohibition under s.167(81).
No reason to interfere with sentences.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cases of this nature warrant upheld sentences.

holdings.text: Statements to customs proved and admissible.
Customs officers not police; voluntary statements admissible.
s.186 does not bar prosecution under s.167(81) after s.167(8) action.
Knowledge of smuggled gold implies intent under s.167(81); conviction upheld even without s.178A presumption.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Customs officers not police officers; statements not hit by s.25 Evidence Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Leo Roy Frey v. The Superintendent District Jail
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on s.186 distinguished; case not directly on point of prosecution under same Act post-confiscation.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of dealing with smuggled gold; confiscation/penalty; presumption of smuggling; no bar to prosecution.

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for confiscation read with Sea Customs Act.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of confessional statements to customs authorities.

outcome.summary: Appeal of Vallabhdas Liladhar abated due to death. Appeals of Vallabhdas Nagjibhai and Narandas Nagjibhai dismissed; convictions and sentences of 6 months RI and Rs.500 fine under s.167(81) Sea Customs Act upheld. No interference with sentences.

key_quotes.text: "Once it is proved that the gold is smuggled gold, it follows that it was brought into the country without payment of duty or in violation of the prohibition or restriction in force."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on intent under s.167(81)

key_quotes.text: "Section 186 was thus meant for permitting prosecutions in addition to action under the Act... it was never intended to act as a bar."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpretation of s.186 allowing parallel proceedings

key_quotes.text: "Customs officers are not police officers and statements made to them were not inadmissible under s.25."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Admissibility of statements relying on precedent
